Nice toffee aroma. Taste is sweet and raisiny, sweet but not sickly palate. Nice bourbon balance,warming, but not boozy. Good bitter finish. Woody aspects also please. A difficult formula to impress me with, but they got everything just about right here. Id probably prefer a slightly cranked down one.

750ml bottle. Pours amber with small head. Nose bourbon, red dried fruits, great caramel piny hops. Taste caramel piny hops some bourbon. Finish light alcohol bourbon caramel piny hops quite resinous. Nice sweetness. Fairly well made nice stuff.

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a thin white head that left some lacing. Aroma of whiskey, oak, caramel and vanilla. Flavor was rich and boozy with caramel, dark fruit, whiskey, oak, toffee and vanilla. very nice

Pours clear copper brown with low tanned head 
Aromas of oak, dried fruits, caramel, hints of bourbon, vanilla, hints of butterscotch 
Taste has notes of whisky, dried fruits, caramel, oak, burned caramel, red fruits, hints of vanilla

Whiskey, almond, oak, cherries, caramel aroma. Crystal clear rust, thick tan head, nice lace. Rich whiskey and almond, dark honey underneath. Maraschino cherries appear and disappear. Strong oak finish. Medium body, soft carbonation. Elegant, complex, well balanced, Superb.

Bottle from a friend. Dark copper color, white head. Bitter taste with resin, nuts, hops, oak, pine, raisins and a bit of toffee. Bitter finish with raisins, resin, hops, toffee, oak, pine and caramel. Excellent barley wine.

Tap at Porter Beer Bar, Atlanta. Colour is deep reddish brown with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Dry fruits, raisins, some vineous elements, some chocolate, some whiskey, hops and malts. Very strong flavors.
Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle poured into a snifter. Clear Amber with small head. Aroma is wood, medium body, low carbonation, and some lacing. Taste is wood, some caramel, and a little whiskey.

Bottle from Brewtopia. Garnet reddish brown with loose head and a little lace. Boozy alcohol aroma at first, then escapes to leave toasted caramel ripe cherry woody whiskey aroma. Toasted caramel maple syrup brown sugar sweetness with woody leafy piney bitterness and long boozy finish. Full body and low carbo. A little overwhelming but Im gonna sip this baby and make it last.

This isnt bad. Theres an off flavor in there somewhere. Aroma was good. Vanilla, bourbon, white chocolate and caramel. Pour was a beautiful deep dark red with a thin off white film for a head. Taste was alright. There was a strong peppery bite that almost tasted like you ate a piece of tree bark. The rest of the aromas were present and full. That one weird flavor brought this beer down. Very light carbonation
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: SIBF 2016, Seattle. Soft light clearish brown. Fresh oak aroma. Clean smooth BW. Juicy banana. Clean, checked alcohol. Soft barrel rounds it out. Nice.

Aroma is mild wood and bourbon mixed with some vanilla and big toffee notes. Taste is a well rounded and easy sweet raisins, dark fruits and a laidback, thick and sweet plum notes. This is a freakin awesome Barley Wine, well rounded tastes and flavors, but I still do like my Ruffian close up in my face with an attitude and ready for some fisticuffs.

750 ml. 2015 vintage. Nice color. Aroma is toffee, candied plums, deep raisins, whiskey. Taste is dates, sugar covered raisins, English malts, alcohol notes. The flavor that lingers the most is oak. Whiskey is here, but huge oak to boot! Finish is sweet, light bitter with some mild warming alcohol. Medium bodied, with a restrained alcohol note. Pretty nice drink.

750ml bottle shared by AirForceHops for my Bday. Thanks, Chris! Bottled March 27, 2015. Pours maple syrup brown with an off white head. Aroma is toffee, vanilla, bourbon, oak. Flavor is toffee, brown bread, vanilla, whiskey, oak. Moderate grassy bitterness in the finish. Alcohol well hidden.

Poured from 750ml bottle dated March 2015 thanks Airforcehops nice ruby brown pour with a nice off white head. Aromas of dark fruit caramel whiskey and vanilla. Taste is caramel vanilla oak dark fruit and some alcohol.
2015 750ml->snifter. Muddy brown ugliness. A: sweet malt, cardboard, oak, vanilla, booze. Taste is the same, though more cardboard. Somewhat watery. Disappointing.

750 ml bottle with DCLawyer and radagast83. Courtesy of DCLawyer, thanks Jason! Bottled 3/27/2015. Murky brown with beige head. Aromas of dark fruit, caramel, booze, whiskey, oak. Tastes of dark fruit, caramel, oak, booze, malt. Medium-light body with a dry finish. Kinda rough.

750ml bottle shared by DCLawyer. Thanks! Bottle was from early 2015. Pours a dark brown-ruby color with a small thin white head. Aroma was sweet boozy caramel, malts, dried fruits. Light woody notes. The flavor is caramel, dark fruits, touch of wet cardboard. Okay, maybe just a little too aged or not aged enough...
Draught at the brewery. Low fluffy white quickly disappearing head. Clear red body. Whisky dominated fruity spicy aroma and flavor with clear notes of alcohol. Low carbonation. Long finish.
Bottle @ Dangerous Bottleshares vol. ?. >Fairly clear copper pour with a small head. Notes of caramel, toffee, butterscotch, dark dried fruits, prunes, some abv burn and light vanilla.

Bottle. Pours hazy brown with a beige head. Aroma of caramel, big hops, sweet dark malts, dark sweet fruits, vanilla and sweet barrel. The taste is sweet with bitter big fat hops, caramel, dark sweet fruits, caramel, barrel and warming alcohol.
Bottle. Pours hazy dark brown with a small brown head. Aromas of hops, vanilla, bitter hops, malt, caramel, fudge. Taste is malty, caramel, orange, hops, vanilla, fudge, earthy.

From bottle. Says 10.2% ABV. Pours a dark hazy amber with a medium sized, oily, off white head. Aroma is so much american barley wine. Caramel, hops, light whisky, nutty. Taste is slight sweet, but surprisingly dry. Oaky, bitter, hoppy. Too hoppy for my style of barley wine. Still decent though.

75CL 2011. Not sure why I kept this beer so long. So glad I did. Prune juice reddish brown. 3 finger head. Smells like old candy, apples, fig and brown sugar with light vanilla. Very smooth. Light, creamy, vanilla and fig. This is lovely.
2015 bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown. Aroma and taste are dark fruits, brown sugar, whiskey, and some oak.

Bottled from Systembolaget
Hazy amber with. Medium, off-white head. 
Sweetish, fruity aroma. 
Sweet fruits, apricots, figs.

Bottle at a tasting in Billdal 160721. Thanks Roland. Fruity caramel aroma, woody, vanilla, raisins, toffee, spicy, bourbon, oak, some licorice and banana. Fruity woody flavor, spicy, hay, bourbon, vanilla, evident oak, caramel, warming alcohol, biscuit notes, raisins, figs. Wonderful beer.

Bottle at SIBF16. Murky, muddy brown. Barrel booze, vanilla and caramel nose. Flavor bumps up the booze, keeps the malts really sweet. Good balance. This isnt a complex beer. Very simple barley wine with a decent bourbon overtone. Not at all bad, not at all anything to write home about.

Amber color with a haze. Sweet malt, caramel, ripe fruits and whisky barrel aromas. Taste is sweet, vanilla, caramel and some dark fruits. The barrel adds a complexity but doesnt add a lot of flavors - nicely balanced. Finish is sweet with the alcohol present. Definitely a better version of the Old Ruffian, but the high price tag is somewhat of a deal breaker.

Sampled on draft at Houghs this beer poured a dark brown color with red highlights and a large creamy beige head that left good lacing. The aroma was sweet, tart and tangy with fruity hops and a bit of wood. The flavor was sweet with moderate fruity hops, a boozy presence, wood, almost vanilla, toasted caramel and dark fruits. Long finish with growing booziness. Moderately full bodied. Nice.

On tap at the brewery. Pours a cloudy copper with medium off white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is candy sugar, booze, oak. Medium body, sweet roast, burnt sugar, oak, boozy finish, really enjoyed this.
Drank during the american beer tasting at Marks place 23-4-2016. Good beer. Lots of alcohol taste. Rich, whisky, very nice.

From a bomber. Pours a crimson-brown and makes a medium beige head with a syrupy consistency and some lacing. Aroma is of malt, yeast, and booze. Tastes of brown sugar, caramel, plum, raisin, and whiskey. The flavors are well balanced and complex. This is a new favorite. Not for every occasion, so break it out for something special. Pairs well with things like prime rib, roasted chicken, or grilled salmon. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear reddish-amberish-brown with a beige head and serious lacing. Aroma of figs, whiskey barrel, and caramel. Taste is sweet, boozy, and lightly bitter. Dry, medium-full bodied, boozy, and smooth. Good, but I have to say I prefer the standard version.

From notes. Enjoyed at the 3rd Annual Barleywine Tasting at Traviss house on February 20. 750 mL bottle. The pour is a dark garnet color with some light brown tinting. There is a thin light tan head and a little bit of lace as it disappears. The aroma is pretty interesting. There is a ton of hops on this right up front. Makes me think of BA Bigfoot for sure. There is a nice light caramel and toffee and a lot of oak char. There is a little vanilla on the back end, but the hops really take back over. The flavor is pretty boozy. There is a lot of alcohol and a soft caramel. The barrel carries a lot of influence, and its just kind of single dimensional. I wish it were a little better. The mouth feel is pretty good, but it is a little light. The carbonation is a little sharp, and the aftertaste is lingeringly hoppy and boozy. This is pretty interesting, but it does remind me heavily of BA Bigfoot, which definitely isnt one of my favorite barleywines.

Bottled March 26th 2015... Opened with no carbonation ... Clear deep Crimson pour with a thin beige head and light sticky lacing .... Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, coconut, dry oak, caramel and roasted malts and a bit of nougat .... Taste is of caramel malts, nougat, vanilla, butterscotch, dry oak, roasted malts and light bourbon notes .... Has a candied sweetness to it ... Finish is dry malty with a sweet and very light bitterness .... Aged one of these once and it was too awful to rate... Do not age this beer. Have this fresh

2012 bottle. This brew pours a hazy mahogany-brown color with a medium beige head that diminishes gradually to a film. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of oak, malt, hops and fruit. Full-bodied with flavors of oaky bourbon, caramel malt, earthy hops and fruit. The finish is oaky with a whiskey and malt aftertaste. Good beer all around.

Another well appreciated heavy weight. A classic caramel malt BW, but backed up by a hefty 80-plus IBUs of American hops. The barreling adds warmth and taste. Dark berries underneath the stronger tastes adds to the balance.  Thick,heavily roasted malt remain the core of this excellent, rich BW.
@ Basunen 16-1-9: ganska intetsägande både i doft och smak. Lite fat och lite malt, annars inget.

(750ml 2015 bottle from Systembolaget web order) Pours a clear pale mahogany with red highlights and small, dense and lingering off-white head with lace. Aroma has a sweet toffee and vanilla fudge core, lots of barrel character with bourbon and vanilla, oak, ashy, maple-smoked bacon, dates, some vague sweet berry notes, a bit of bready character to the malt. Flavour holds less sweetness and vanilla than the nose, with a relatively dry character for a big barley wine. The malt core has bits of toffee and caramel along with some breadiness like sweet dessert buns, a good helping of fairly hot bourbon with less vanilla and more whiskey grain and wood notes. A bit of sweet dried pit fruit in the middle - some dates but also apricot and maybe prune. Lots more oak builds towards the finish, tobacco and leather along with toasted wood. Finish is bone dry with low alcohol heat, whiskey, wood, light toast and maybe a bit of bittering hop. Medium full slightly oily body with light-medium carb. Quite a nice barrel-aged barley wine, not cloying at all.

Pours dark amber with a foamy tan head. Aromas of caramel, toffee, molasses, dates, figs, slight liqourice, oak notes, roasted malts. Taste is a very nice mixture between smoked honey and malty backbone. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2015 750 ml bottle into snifter, bottled on 3/27/2015. Pours hazy deep reddish brown color with a 1-2 finger dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a thin cap that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a light amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big raisin, plum, cherry, fig, date, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, vanilla, molasses, bourbon, brown bread, toasted oak, light citrus/pine, floral, grass, and oak/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, bourbon barrel, and light citrus/piney hop notes; with great strength. Taste of huge raisin, plum, cherry, fig, date, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, vanilla, molasses, bourbon, brown bread, toasted oak, light coconut, light citrus/pine, floral, grass, and oak/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate pine bitterness and bourbon/oak spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of raisin, plum, fig, cherry, date, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, vanilla, molasses, bourbon, brown sugar, and oak/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, bourbon barrel, and light citrus/piney hop flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Some slight dryness from bitterness as well. Light-medium carbonation and fairly full bodied; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/silky, and slightly sticky mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a light warmth lingering after the finish. Overall this is an incredible barrel aged American barleywine. All around awesome complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/bready malt, bourbon barrel, and light citrus/piney hop flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the big ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

Bottle. Light hazy deep copper liquid with small to medium white off-white head. Aroma of raw sugar, wort, anice, bread and toffee. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with notes of toffee, raw sugar, booze, anice and bourbon. Medium to full bodied with medium carbonation.

750 ml bottle from Systembolaget. Hazy red amber with off white head. Caramel, vinous smell with some whisky and alcohol. Taste is caramel,,oak, over ripe fruit, whiskey, rhum, toffee, syrup and dried fruit. Semi sweet with medium bitterness and low carbonation.

Bottle from 2011. Pours deep reddish chestnut, small beige head, some residual and lacing. Aroma is hugely oaky, vinous, slightly Bretty, whiskey. Flavor is light sweet, some tartness, loads of oak tannins, some funk, whiskey, dry sherry. Medium body. Interesting what 5 years has done to this one.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy amber brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty woody caramel bourbon aroma. Fruity malty woody caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty woody caramel bourbon vanilla finish.
Pours a dark redish-brown. Has a strong caramel and dark alcohol flavor. Strong flavor of caramel, dark alcohol, and malts. Not much different than the non-barrel version.

Fra flaske på Cardinal M2 sep-15: Sigmund overgår seg selv og ruller ut den ene h¨jdaren etter den andre (La Trappe Quadrupel Oak Aged, Stone Double Bastard, for å nevne noen). Denne har lett grumset brunlig farge med kort skum. Saftig, lekker og balansert med sviskeplommer, rosiner, sherrytoner, vanilje og amerkanske whiskeyfat. Life is indeed good.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2015 Shared bottle at Mi2 at Cardinal 28.09.15 and 26.10.15. Slightly hazy brown. Small head with big bubbles, Complex aroma, with dry malt, dry herbs and brown booze. Similar taste, also with dried fruits. Plums and cherries. Warming aftertaste.

Shared bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger. Pours hazy dark brown with a weak beige head. Aroma is malty, weak and inviting. Taste is moderate sweet grtainy malts, with a decent dry clean hoppy finish. Nice.
Shared bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger. Pours hazy light brown with off-white head. Aroma of caramel, oak, vanilla, fermented fruits. Tastes slightly sweet, but still well balanced.
Shared 750 ml bottle at Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. Will write a proper rating shortly, when I have a full bottle. This is one hell of a beer!
Flaska från systembolaget. Mycket söt Bourbon och torkad frukt i doften, detsamma i smaken med en värmande alkohol i bakgrunden. God!

Deep mahogony hue with a creamy one finger head. Nose has a lot going on with sweet malty notes and caramel, also a nutty note, vanilla, bourbon. Flavour is very malty, toasted bread, toffee, vanilla, bit of booze at the end and a hoppy, bitter bite. Nice and smooth texture, medium big mouthfeel and just enough carbonation.

Red with small light tan head. Caramel, tobacco, and slightly floral aroma. Not overly boozy. Slight bitterness, with almonds and some chocolate flavors.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at 101 Beer Kitchen Gahanna on 9/1/15. Clear reddish brown pour with a thin beige head. Aroma of grainy malt, caramel, bourbon and slight chocolate. Malty and caramelly flavor with piney hop and bourbon before a dry hop and caramel finish.

Bottled:Colour is brown. Head is kind of smallish. Aroma is malty; chocolate, toffee and almonds. Some hops and alcohol. Somewhat sticky mouthfeel. Taste is chocolate, toffee, almonds, cherries, hops and alcohol. Bitter finish.Pretty good, but the ordinary Old Ruffian is much better.

Pours deep murky brown with medium tall off-white head. Aroma of butterscotch, toffee, bourbon, vanilla and light resin. Taste is caramel sweet with burnt notes and nuts, boozy slightly bitter finish. Rich and creamy body with soft carbonation.

August 22, 2015. Bottled match 16, 2015. 
Dark red with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma is toffee, berries, alcohol, plum, pine and whiskey. Taste is sweet with toffee, resin, black berries, light bitter slight roasted and alcohol notes. Finish is sweet, light bitter with some slight harsh notes and warming alcohol.
Medium bodied, average carbonation. Expected more, bit of a let down.

Bottle from Great Divide- from the last run they did in stranahan barrels. Pours a nice toffee orange with a white head. Nose is some caramel and toffee, vanilla, oak, bourbon, slight oxidation, and some brandy notes. Flavor hits on all cylinders- toffee, caramel, vanilla, oak, some brandy, slight oxidation, and hints of sweetness. Medium in body and one of the best aged beers I have pulled out of the cellar. Delicious overall.
(En fût au Common Theory Public House): Caramel coulant, vanille liquoreuse, raisins verts et une touche de fumée provenant dun barleywine bien ficellé qui nexagère pas dans leffet de la barrique.

Bottle. Been wanting to try this for a long time. Pours a slightly cloudy medium brown, with modest head and some lacing. Aroma is more subdued than I would have thought, with malt, caramel, and metal notes. Taste is not a heavy or intense as I was hoping for. Moderately bitter, little on the dry side, with some coffee flavor. Not simple, but I was hoping for more complexity. I really dont get a lot of barrel from this. Finishes with bitterness as the main feature. Its not bad, but as one of the most expensive beers youll find, and barrel aging, I was pretty disappointed.

750 from Capones. Pours turbid burnt sienna with 2-finger fluffy, well-retained khaki head. Nose is caramel malt, oak, whiskey, molasses, hp[s. Tastes rich, oaky, with heavy whiskey, caramel, alcohol heat, and hops, and heavy hops, but I question the 85-90 IBUs. Very complex, tons of wood and whiskey throughout. Delicious.

Bottle at home. Clear amber pour, thin off-white head. Aroma is full of bourbon, vanilla, sugary malts, caramel and slightly spicy. Flavor is quite sweet, oak, vanilla, bourbon and very smooth. Great balance, nice brew.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel Florentin. Thanks David Cohen. Hazy amber. Aroma of malt, caramel, vanilla, wood, stale hops and alcohol. Sweet flavor with malt, caramel, vanilla, wood, whiskey, some bitter stale hops, and alcohol. Medium-bodied.
Bottle @ ZEBF 2015. Aroma of ripe fruit, raisin and malt. Taste is very sweet, with raisin and ripe red fruit. This is close to a port wine.

It pours a cloudy brown with a full brown head. It has aroma of molasses, raisins, figs, and brown sugar. It has flavors of sweet figs, whiskey, oak, molasses, and dark fruits. It has a fine bitter finish.
Sample at Hopfest 2015. Comes a dark reddish brown with a decent beige head. Aroma of fruit, malt, and whiskey. Taste is dark fruit, caramel malt, whiskey, and wood. Very nice.

Bottle from Greens. Dark ruby red pour with a thick, fluffy beige head. Big bubbles. Big bourbon, woody aroma jumped from the glass, caramel malt, touch of vanilla and booze. Flavors were also bourbon heavy, slightly sweet vanilla and caramel. Finish was slightly unpleasant with heavy bourbon and a lingering bitterness. Surprisingly thinnish mouthfeel, moderate carbonation. A bit rough around the edges, maybe some time will smooth this out. Was really looking forward to this!
Draft at GD. Dry, aromatic barley wine - complex, a little citrus, fine aroma. Glad I got a chance to try it.
Okay, but somewhat of a disappointment based on style and previous ratings.

Aromas of oak, toffee, figs, raisins, molasses, beef jerky, leather, whiskey, spices, herbs and heavy liquid malt extract syrup. Appears a deep, dark mahogany with a purple tint and no foam at all. Taste is huge barrel notes, oak, raisin and whiskey upfront. Mid palate comes a quick sweetness of pitted dark fruits, plums, figs, dates and toffee. Finishes smooth with sharp bitterness, herbs, spices, whiskey, oak, melted caramel, nougat, blackberry juice and barrel wood. Overall, this beer is really impressive. Comes in layers of complexity and huge booze comes out as it warms. Really well done. The barrel did wonders.

Not sure if this is 2013 or 2011 vintage

Pours a murky walnut color, head is a small 1/4 inch and creme colored. Lacing is above average and head retention is average.

Smell is of rich toffee and caramel candy. Next is roasted malt, charred oak and whiskey with a hint of vanilla. Hops arent present and alcohol is definitely there.

Taste is heavy on caramel, butterscotch, diacetyls, and charred oak. Some whiskey burn is also present on the back end. Weird vinegar/acidic finish

Mouthfeel is syrupy, not as viscous as maple syrup, more like cough syrup. Carbonation levels were par for style and age. Wish head was present to add some layers to beer.

Overall good beer but at 25 bucks a pop, not worth the price. There were some off flavors that detracted from the beer reaching elite status. Glad to have tried it and always intrigued to get my hands on anything Great Divide releases.
Bottle at BA tasting. Pours a clear copper golden color. Aromas of dark fruits vanilla caramel. Light barrel character. Very well done.

750ml bottle 213/461, bottled 08/2008, purchased at the brewery in october 2008, dark brown color, with a beige head, nice boozy phenolic, mint chocolate, dark dried fruit, vanilla oak barrel nose, with some toffee, caramelized, toasted, pale malt, caramel, bourbonish, faint floral leafy, grassy hop, toasted bread crumb accents, and a faint biscuity crackery, cocoa, subtle coconut, raisiny note in the aroma follows through on a full-bodied palate, with a very nice warmth whiskyish oak barrel, vanilla bourbonish, dark dried fruit, toffee, caramelized, toasted, pale, bready malty character, with some raisiny, faint leafy, grassy hop, caramelized bread crumb, faint sponge toffee, raisin pie crust, caramelized nut flavours, leading towards a good warming, toffee, caramel, dark dried fruit, lingering whisky vanilla oak, bourbonish coconut oak barrel booziness finish.
completely infected, plastic and battery acid are the aromas i got, diapers, 6 month old candy bar, caramel, and trash are the fiavors. Almost vomitted.

750 ml bottle at Hasse. Dark amber with off white head. Aroma sweet and malty with lots of whisky and wood, booze, plums and raisins. Taste is thick and sweet, wood, bourbon, sherry, raisins, plums and various dried fruit

Bottle 3444. Snifter, shared with friends. 
Appearance is deep red brown. Good head which dissipated quickly. 

Nose is Big citrus. 

Orange peel mixed with dried fruits. Sweet plums. Surprising amount of carbonation. Can't taste the whiskey at all. 

No real lingering taste.

Bottle: Thanks Rene: Served in a taster: 
Creamy head on top of a hazy amber colored beer.
Aromas of barley malts, bourbon, light wild yeast, wood and cream.
Flavours of malts, bourbon, bitter, barley malts, some cream, corn, sweetbitter.
Aftertaste is sweetbitter, wood, barley malts, bourbon.
Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel, medium to fuller body and a creamy texture.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle @ home. Aroma is caramel, red fruit notes, light mocca, tangy red wine notes. Flavour is quite sweet with malt and caramel, again with some tangy red wine and oak barrel notes.

Bottle shared @ tasting. Hazy red color, medium sized beige head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is malts, liquor, sweetness, but also something a little weird I cant put my finger on. Taste malts, sweetness, liquor, wood, overripe fruits, alcohol. Quite heavy, and not as good as I had expected. Perhaps my expectations were a bit too high.

Bottle shared thanks to Benzai. Pours cloudy brown with a ring tan head. Aroma of rich malt, oak, vanilla overripe dark fruit, raisins and some sweet dried fruit. Flavour is heavy sweet and light moderate bitter. Full bodied with light carbonation.

750ml bottle, 2013 vintage. Aroma of strong oak and malt sweetness, with notes of whiskey, toffee, cherry, vanilla, caramel, earthiness, dark bread, faint spices and peppery alcohol in the background, the oak really coming to the fore, though. Murky, deep reddish-brown in color with a very fine, uneven and lasting head, leaving some fairly spectacular lacing behind as well. Flavor profile shows a good amount of oak even after well over a year in the cellar, along with plenty of rich, dark, sugary malt sweetness, lightly tart cherry, touches of toasted coconut and vanilla, brown sugar, and surprisingly prominent spicy hop bitterness, some peppery alcohol, wood and tea-like herbal tinges making their presence felt here late as well. Fine but persistent carbonation on the palate, gently tannic, tart and warming, body is fittingly gigantic. Far more challenging than Old Ruffian but not without its own merits and intrigue.

"upon opening, I was still greeted with more hops than Id expect after a long barrel aging process. upon pouring, however, the hops are almost totally replaced in the aroma by woody vanilla, caramel, and toffee. very nice aroma. The look is fairly typical for a barleywine, which is nice, but not standout. smallish head. the flavor achieves a balance somehow between the sweet malt, whiskey, wood, vanilla, and hops...it manages to be strong in both sweet and hoppy without one being totally overpowering, although there is nothing delicate about this complex brew. In fact, our palates were so assaulted, this beer marked the start and finish of my tasting for the night. at 50+ degrees, the sweet and whiskey are a little more in the forefront, with the bittering and drying hops in the finish. As the beer gets closer to room temp, the hops take over a bit from the whiskey. A very nice beer for sure, and a rare treat, but for the price, the only way Id get this again is to do a vertical tasting of regular/oak/and barrel aged Old Ruffians. 7/12 - 2011 batch, still not as complex as the base, due to the whiskey being in the fore, but pretty damn good. up a tenth of a point."

From notes. Tasted on 6/30/12 at the 1st Annual Chimipalooza, from an older 750mL bottle. Pours hazy dark amber with an average tan head that leaves a thick collar of lace. The nose is tons of maple, caramel and toffee, vanilla and cinnamon oak, and some brown sugar. The flavor is a touch sweet up front, with the same maple, caramel, toffee, and brown sugar malt, along with vanilla and cinnamon oak, and some alcoholic heat. The body is full and sticky with just lighter than average carbonation and a long maple, toffee, caramel, and cinnamon oak finish.
Nice pour with big pillow head,slight tannish. Fantastic aroma of vanilla and oak as description states. Flavor is fantastic with rich caramel, hops and bourbon. Such a great all around beer!!!

It was a distinct pleasure to share argo0s 9,000th rating with this beer, the DC crew and displaced portions of the Richmond and NC crews - thanks, gentlemen. Murky plum color, no head or lacing. Aroma of caramel and butterscotch and booze. Taste is boozy caramel, some vanilla toward the end. OK.

Bottle in trade from Adam. Big thanks for a big want to a great trader. Looks like an 11 on the bottle so I am assuming this is a 2011 bottle, 750 ml, poured 8/17/14. Bottle #1113. Pours muddy brown with a creamy two finger off white head. Awesome aroma of whiskey, oak, vanilla, interestingly some chocolate here, toffee, and lots of figs and some brown sugar. Flavor is big time bourbon but super smooth, oak, massive vanilla tones, figs, brown sugar, some caramel, lingering vanilla oakiness. Medium to heavy bodied, medium plus carbonation, smooth finish with nearly no booze burn. Wow this is really nice.

Inte det absolut bästa dom någonsin gjort men helt klart god att dricka. 
Snygg flaska som vanligt.

(Had this on tap at Great Divide Brewery; the bartender said it was aged 11 months in Fireside Whiskey barrels, and it seemed redundant to make a new listing) Murky woody copper under a thin rocky cap. Absolutely incredible aroma of toasted caramel and oak char, lots of vanilla chip cookies, and a bright plum and black cherry boozy note. Tastes absolutely magnificent with boozy notes of plum and raisin and toasted caramel, oak, vanilla, char, black cherry, fruity whiskey, more raisin and cherry, more caramel and toasted oak, and a little more sweet candied booze. Amazeballs.
750mL bottle from CLE beer week 2013? this is really sweet lots of vanilla and almost a hint of coconut solid beer with big beefy flavor, Im diggin the stranahan flavor.

Aroma Is not strong for the style. Turpentine, tar, apple, pear. Look is creamy head, orangeish brown. Cloudy. Legs. Taste is more apples, tar-ish aroma is woody in tasting it. Caramel. Alcohol well masked. Mot completely hidden of course at almost 13%, ....actually the bottle says 10.2%. (2012)
 But still impressive. 
 Liking it more as I drink (but isnt that always the case). Smooth, sour aftertaste.

2009 bottle sent to me by someone long ago. Thanks, though I cant remember your name. Bottle 403/1188

A: Placid brown with no head - even after a hard pour. Nice lacing.

N: Bourbon and its evidence of caramel and vanilla. Hops, pineapple, lots and lots of wood. A touch of cherry and chocolate. 

T: Intense wood bitterness. Some residual hopping in here, and the bourbon/malt sweetness gets to the point of cloying.

M: Very oily. Heavy and almost completely lacking in carbonation.

O: Intense barleywine thats still too much. The non-bubbles crushed the tongue and I got pretty sick of it pretty fast. On the other hand, the 2009 used to be one of the worst beers Ive ever had, and this at least better. Not worth half the 35 dollars it costs, though.

A- Pours a deep reddish brown hue with a massive frothy pecan colored head that leaves tons of lacing on the way down.

S- Berries, brown sugar, light caramel

T- Brown sugar, lots of bourbon notes, creamy all the way through with hints of alcohol toward the end.

M- Medium carbonation, thick and creamy.

D- Excellent beer but I think it loses a bit in the barrel.

HMOG 2014. One of the bottles I brought that I have been starring at for about a year. Really was excited to get this one under my belt. Dry biscuit nose with deep caramel and ripe sweet fruit, bourbon, vanilla. Taste was velvety smooth buttery (in a good way) bourbon, caramel, oaky vanilla. Sweet lingering finish that coats the mouth. Real nice.
HMOG 2014. Honestly never thought Id see this so I had just put it out of my mind. Malty, earthy, dirty aroma. Red fruit cherry and plum flavors. Well done and very smooth.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2014 Bottle: Dark, burnt brown & tan color with a nicely crafted, fine-bubbled, tan leather head on tap that lasts surprisingly long for a barley wine. Aroma is boozy & sweet; lots of oak, light vanillin, & warm, alcoholic lathered molasses. Little dark fruit essence; prunes & dates, covered in a bourbon-caramel drizzle. Taste has a larger malty caramel & toffee presence with deeper molasses underneath... More sweet & delicate than the aroma. Sweet, toasted brown sugar, grapes, raisins, prunes, & black cherries abound, all soaked in booze & coated in caramelized sugar. Bourbon is still lighter on the palate than the nose, however... Actually the oak itself overpowers the bourbon flavors... Lots of oak in this one, especially in the finish. Good inductions of vanilla, mild cinnamon, raisins, & sweet sugary dates in the aftertaste. Nice BA barley wine.

2012 bottle split the other night with my wife. pours hazy red amber, minimal cream hued head. vanilla, caramel and bourbon nose. mouth demnstrates much of the same with toffee and some oak. big creamy body, major boost.
sample at Food Bank bottle share. great beer, caramel colored pour, rich caramel & toffee maltiness, oaky, vanila & whiskey notes. vast flavors blend together very nicely. great beer

2008 bottle, 750 mL, #336/461. Poured clear, rich amber with a dusting of smoked beige head. The aroma picked up sweet and smokey aged bourbon, oak, and peppery alcohol.. touches of fig and licorice too.. more barrel than base beer, but it was solid. The flavor found spicy bourbon and vinous notes on the tip of the tongue.. warm licorice, vanilla, and dark fruits followed.. finished with peppery spice, bourbon, and aged malts. Heavy-bodied with low-ish carbonation.. coating, well-aged, and well-balanced. Loved it!

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2014 2009 bootle. meaty old toffee. deep sweet whiskey boosted. little to no carbonation. warming booze. some dough. a bit too sweet. a touch too doughy. warming whiskey is swell enough. fine.

vintage 2011
Thanks Pixieskid

Pours nice dark amber with fleeting yellow foam. Nose is bourbon barrels, vitamins, burnt caramel. As it warms, its like cinnamon toast crunch - hella cool. Flavor is like a cinnamon bun - rich and sweet with caramel, dark malts and herbal/spice qualities. Really not doing justice with that sentence. Medium bodied with a simple syrup tone and reserved carb. Good beer, wish I would have bought some when I had the chance a couple years ago.

Serving type: bottle

06-21-2012

750 mL at the parentals with my dad, bottle in 2011. Pour is murky brown with a small tan head that quickly dissipated. Big bourbon, caramelly, bready, oxidized, raisiny, toffee, figgy, plummy, slightly earthy, and sherry aroma. Taste is big figs, dates, sweet cherries, caramel, huge bourbon, wood, toffee, and tangy with a slight alcoholic bite on the backend. Creamy mouthfeel with soft carbonation. I definitely prefer the original and this one is way overpowered by the barrel.

Bottled 750ml PBFVIII 11.8%
Hazy nut brown color, small steady off-white head. Alcohol, berries, vanilla, whiskey in the nose. Full-bodied. Lots of hops, wood and alcohol. Vanilla notes, sweetish. A bit young and straightforward alcoholic but a good beer.
Dunkel malziger, deutlich süßer Antrunk. Dennoch sehr süffig, schokoladig werdend. Süffig süß bleibend, karamelliger, holzig, sehr weich. Gut! 11/12/12/11/11/11

Bottle 750ml.
Pours burgundy with low beige head.Good lacing. Aroma is of whiskey, caramel, malt, sugar. Taste is of malt, slight bitterness. Palate: Medium body. Overall: Not bad at all. Slightly cloying, but a pretty good sipper.

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by Jean-Michaël, thanks! Deep amber with a small beige head and small lacing. Aroma is interesting with toffee, caramel, oak, fruity notes, some sweetness and bourbon. Taste is moderately sweet with oak, toffee, wood, bourbon and fruits. Warming alcohol. Medium to full body. Moderate carbonation. Good Barley Wine. Not as complex as the best of the style, but definitely enjoyable. A lot of wood in there. Surprisingly not as well balanced as most of Great Divide products (Yeti series, for example, is a example of balance).

pours hazy brown-reddish with a light beige cap, some retention and lacing. fruity and caramel-ish malts, touch of chocolate, vanilla bourbon, candied and drird dark red fruitiness, grass, pepper, soft oak tannins, bit of chocolate, few ashy notes. moderate carbonation, medium body - oily, some sweetness - not cloying though, grassy-spicy-oaky finish. enjoyed it!

Bottle. Deep copper-red pour, nice lacing. Caramelized malt, toffee aroma, rich sweet fruity notes with lots and lots of candy bourbon aromas, vanilla. Taste is sweet, maybe a tad cloyingly so, nice bourbony warmth, quite woody. Palate is heavy, nice warming alcohol. Tasty.
Bottle sampled at a tasting. From notes. Boozy with caramel and vanilla. Loads of bourbon and oak. Wow, I would love a bottle all to myself.

A: Dark Amber Hue, Passes Mild Light, Off White Head Ring, Minimal Lacing

S: Mild Butterscotch, Mild Caramel, Mild Toffee

T: Caramel, Mild Butterscotch

M: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet, Mildly Boozy

Overall, definitely not worth the price of admission for 35/bottle.

75 cl bottle (11.8% abv) @ PBF 2013. Bottle No. 3892.
Pours dark hazy orange color with a medium sized lasting head. Aroma of ripe fruits, sweet caramel, hops, vanilla, mild bourbon notes and faint toffee. Flavor of sweet caramel, ripe fruits, vanilla, bourbon and mild hops. Quite sticky sweet, but good, could age well.
6415

750 ml bottle @ PBF 2013.
Pours a dark copper amber colour with a white head. Aroma is rather strong on whiskey notes, biscuit, dark chocolate and wet wool. Flavour of sweet caramel malts, whiskey, bread, dark chocolate, tangy wood, vanilla and cinnamon. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Finishes sweet, complex, chocolatey. Hard to find the base beer here, as this feels like a completely different beer. Great stuff.

Bottled (2012 vintage -11.8%) at PBF.  Clear mahogany colour, minimal head. Caramel mingle with vanilla and oak up front. Sweet, full bodied with rounded mouthfeel. Plenty pof bourbon, but it goes very well with the caramelly malt. Driven by sweet malt and oaky bourbon. Warming finish where the bitterness is balanced by all the malt.

750ml bottle @ PBF 2013. Thanks wchesser!
Bottle #3862 - Pours dark brownish orange with a smooth head. Aroma of sweet syrupy malts, caramel, wood, oak, hints of whisky and vanilla. Taste is sweet, malty, hoppy, caramely, woody and oaky with notes of vanilla, whisky and syrup. Finish is sweetish and caramely with loads of caramel, syrup, wood, oak, whisky and vanilla. Quite complex, sweet and malty. Well balanced and tasty, but perhaps a tad too sweet for my taste.

75 cl bottle (11.8%, vintage 2012?) @ PBF VIII. Bottle number 3862.
Aroma has lots of vanilla, some oaky notes and . Flavour has quite strong booze sting at first. Finishes with harsh malt, some caramel, strong vanilla and some woody notes that grow stronger towards the end of the glass. Wine-like slow sipper, still liked the basic Old Ruffian More.

Bottle..Pour is brown with a creamy head..Nose is sweet, maple, barrel, caramel, toffee. Fig, bourbon...Taste is nice oak, dry, sweetness, caramel, toffee, vanilla, alcohol..such a nice beer.

From a really old rating note I found while packing the house for a move. Seems like I enjoyed it: Big sweet, boozy, brown sugar, bread, toffee. Good warmth. Wood, dry fruit. Very nice. 8.2

Well worth the 100. Perfect body, super flavors. Bourbon to the max with an easy flavor finish.  Vanilla and spicy cinammon finish. Best beer ive had from them.

Bottle #266 of 461.  Year 08, bottle courtesy of Brewtopia!!  Back to Colorado for my rating. Even though Ive had this beer every year its been out I have never rated it. It seems fitting that I get a bottle from the first year to see how it handles the year of time. 

Ill say this, its time to start a vertical of this one. 

Murky dark brown sugar pour. Still carbonated well and oxidized just right by the barrel aging. Lots of stuff left on the bottom of the bottle fr years of proper cellaring. Sweet malty smell. Nothing but grain, bourbon, oak and dried tree fruits. Taste is malty goodness into the dries tree fruits with an oakey, vanilla, bourbon tannin biting the tongue for several minutes after the first sip. 

Dont hesitate @ the 25-30$ price tag. U wont be disappointed.
Bottle. Pour is deep hazy reddish brown with a small tan head. Aroma is full of old rich malt, cobweb, and light caramel. Flavor is quite sweet with notes of fruit and brown sugar. Very sweet.

750 ml bottle received in trade. Thank you! Pours clear dark amber with a rather thin offwhite head that quickly dissipates while leaving some trace on the glass. Smell is sweet, fruity and malty with sweet dark bread, caramel, toffee, vanilla fudge, oak, overripe tropical fruits, bourbon, roasted nuts, dried dark fruits, caramelized apples, hay, coconut milk, whisky, hints of charred wood, hints of moist moss and subtle hints of smoked meats. Taste is sweet, tiny bitter, fruity and malty with caramel, toffee, biscuits, vanilla fudge, alcohol, grass, charred wood,  overripe tropical fruits, raisins, prunes, figs, bourbon, roasted nuts, pine needles, coconut, lemon zest, resin and hints of grapefruit rinds, smoke and moist leaves. Mouthfeel is round, soft, creamy, smooth, boozy and full bodied. Finish is sweet, bitter malty and fruity with caramel, biscuits, vanilla fudge, bourbon, charred wood, roasted nuts, grass, pine needles, sweet dark bread and hints of grapefruit rind. Very nice big beer. A less rough ruffian but oh so smooth and tasty.

2012 bottle (#1523). Pours a murky, dark reddish-brown with a khaki one-finger head. Sweet whiskey aroma with a ton of caramel, toffee, and roasted nuts. Smooth sweetness from the first sip with toffee as the predominant flavor along light booze, creamy caramel, a hint of oak and tobacco, and a sugary, buttery note reminiscent of fresh-baked pecan pie. Its not nearly as hot as I expected. Medium body with an incredibly smooth texture and long, resiny finish. A gorgeous sipper.

Bomber.  Ruby maple pour with more carbonation than I was expecting for the style.  Nose of toffee, caramel and bready malts.  Taste follows the nose with very subdued hops and some vanilla and barrel.  Mouth is too carbonated for my liking on this style.  Good but not great.

Bottle @ home. Clear chestnut body with a tiny offwhite head. Aroma is alcohol, dark fruits, raisins, wood, vanilla notes. Flavor is raisins, plums, toffee, wood, tobacco, boozy end.

Bottle from Bubbles in Castle Rock I think. Pours deep mahogany with tan head. Aromas of sweet caramel, vanilla, oak, rich malts, and touch of coconut. Flavors of nice sweet and thick malts, caramel, vanilla, oak, and touch of whiskey, Nice and sweet, but not overdone. This one has aged quite nice. Great beer.

Mahogany pour with medium sized head and lacing. Color of the foam was khaki. Aromas of caramel, dark fruit, sugar, sweetness, oak, and grain. Flavor was much of the same with a lot of bitter tasting hops coming through. More of a triple ipa or a really hoppy barleyine if u ask me. Medium to full mouth. The B.a version was a lot more balanced and drinkable then regular.

750 ml bottle served in a Southern Tier tulip. 2012 vintage.

A: Pours a murky sienna color with a khaki head forming on the pour. It recedes to a thick ring that leaves some splotchy lace down the glass.

S: Whiskey barrel upfront with some caramel and dark fruits. Chocolate covered raisins with a sweet malt bill.

T: More dark fruits with a whiskey barrel sweetness. Oak barrel, brown sugar with a nice roasted malt backing. The whiskey comes back with a sharp zing on the finish, but theres enough sweetness to balance it out.

M: Medium heavy bodied with a smooth mouthfeel. Medium low carbonation level.

O: I definitely enjoyed this one. The whiskey bite is sharp, but the booze is well hidden and it isnt hot at all.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle RB Århus tasting @ Christers, courtesy of adnielsen, huge thanks Aaron. 2012 vintage # 3347. Pours rusty brown with a slowly fading offwhite head. Aroma of rich malt, caramel, oak, vanilla, coconuts, light bourbon. Flavor is rich malty, caramel, oak, vanilla, rich bourbon, dark fruits, very smoth and velbalanced. Full body, soft carbonation, warming alcohol in the finish. 270213

Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Courtesy of adnielsen. Thanks a lot, Aaron, for another top beer! Hazy reddish amber with a lasting off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit, vanilla, wood and whisky. Flavor is very sweet and rather bitter. Sweet finish with warming alcohol. Smooth and oily. 270213

Bottle courtesy adnielsen. Clear dark amber/brown with small tan head. Aroma is malt, toasted, caramel, oak, vanilla, whiskey and a little toffee. Flavour is malt, caramel, vanilla, oak, wood, medium sweet, toasted, toffee and whiskey. Smooth.

Bottle courtesy adnielsen. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark amber. Aroma and taste are rich fruits, little vanilla, caramel, wood, alcohol, malt, notes of candy sugar and hops. Long bitter finish.

Shared bottle with Timfoolery. Pours a murky brown. A little too tart for my taste. Almost like sour cherries. I was severely disappointed. Maybe a bad bottle....might have to try again.

Bottle from someone. Thoughts are this bottle of 2011 is infected. Sort of a tart taste, even though I still taste the whiskey, barely. Almost like a wine barrel...taste the "cherry." Whatever, not impressed at all.

Bomber from trade with DrSilverworm.  Bottle number 1576, unknown vintage.  Pours a murky dark brown color with a big bubbly head that lingers a bit.  Nice complex aroma of whiskey, toffee, tobacco, vanilla, butterscotch, caramel, and biscuits.  Taste is equally complex.  All of the aromas balance pretty well, glad that the whiskey does not overpower.  Brown sugar and whiskey sweetness is a bit over the top but not too bad.  Really thick, sticky, and chewy mouthfeel.  A very nice sipping barley wine.

Aroma of sweet whiskey, raisin, and toffee.  Pours deep red with very small film.  Taste is amazing.  Solid barleywine notes of sweet dates, cherry peel, caramel, candy Apple, and a nice pine hop.  This is a wonderful brew.

Bottle: The aroma consists of caramel, toffee, fruit, coconut, and bourbon. Its a hazy orangish-brown with a small beige head. The flavor starts with moderate-heavy caramel, toffee, and fruit. Then finish has raisin, coconut,bourbon, and a hint of mint. Its medium bodied with light-moderate carbonation.

This isnt a monstrously complex beer, but it is so damn smooth and it does what it does so well that it deserves the high rating.  Pours a deep brown mahogany color with very little head.  The aroma is super concentrated with notes of burned wood, caramel, biscuit, toffee, and butterscotch.  On the palate, you can taste a tinge of vanilla from the barrel, but its mostly a strong caramel, beady sweetness.  Super clean finish considering how sweet it is.  Lovely!

Bottle number 4262 poured a muddy brown in color with a thin coating of tan head. Aroma has vanilla, oak, dusty hops, sweet whiskey, brown sugar, and light heat. Mouth feel is medium heavy with a nice coating and plenty of carbonation for a barrel aged beer. Flavor has aged hops, plenty of barrel wood, vanilla, mellow whiskey, brown sugar sweetness, and mellow heat going into the finish. This is a nice combination because the barrel treatment does not take over but rather mellows nicely into the base beer complimenting instead of dominating.
HAvent had the regular to compare but this is a solid BA barleywine, plenty of oak and vanilla form the barrel.
Amber with a large head of beige foam. Odd nutty and musty aroma. Tart on the palate, semi-drying.

Sample, brown bottle, 750 ml, 11.8%, bottle 3347; eye: dark ruby, clear, tiny ring of pale brown head, light lacing; nose: woody, whisky, caramel, malt, bourbon, light dark fruits, anise, molasses, light vanilla; mouth: woody, whisky, caramel, malt, light hops, dark fruits, anise, molasses, light resinous hops, finale in malt with presence of molasses, full body, below-average carbonation, mildly bitter, lightly sweet, lightly alcoholic texture; overall: quite fine

Échantillon, bouteille brune, 750 ml, 11,8 %, bouteille 3347; il : rubis foncé, limpide, petit anneau de mousse brun pâle, légère dentelle; nez : boisé, whisky, caramel, malt, bourbon, léger fruits noirs, anis, mélasse, léger vanille; bouche : boisé, whisky, caramel, malt, léger houblon, fruits noirs, anis, mélasse, léger houblon résineux, finale en malt avec présence de mélasse, corsée, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement amère, légèrement sucrée, texture légèrement alcoolique; en résumé : bien bon

750mL bottle, pours a dirty dark amber with a medium, quickly-dissipating beige head. Aroma of deep dark fruits, brown sugar,    Flavour is exceedingly complex, with brown sugar, dark dried fruits (figs, dates), candied sugar, subtle whiskey barrel notes that are never overbearing, and a touch of alcohol. Despite 20 months in the whiskey barrels, the barrels never dominate the already complex base beer, but rather accentuate it, while the hops are no longer very noticeable. Extremely complex, sweet but not cloying, finishing on brown sugar notes. I actually prefer the regular Old Ruffian slightly more, but this is an enjoyable delicacy.

Bottle from the source.  2011.  Murky red-brown pour with a thin yellow head.  Aroma of aged/degraded hops, thick brown sugar, whiskey, and mixed dark fruit.  Flavor is layered with sweet brown sugar and whiskey at the top, followed by dark fruit with vinous characteristics, moderate hop bitterness, and light peppery, alcohol finish.  Medium palate presence with perfect carbonation level.  A very easy drinking barrel-aged beer with just the right amount of malt sweetness and hop bitterness without covering the barrel flavor.  Booze and whiskey characteristics pretty much dead-on as well.

Bottle.  Pours a dark, cloudy amber color.  Aroma is sweet with caramel, vanilla, and bourbon.  This smells amazing.  Taste follows the nose with vanilla, bourbon, caramel, and dark fruits coming through.  Not too much bourbon in this one, its there, but not dominating or too "hot".  Very good and would love to try this again.
December 15, 2012 bottle via trade.  Muddy brown pour with some head and lacing.  Aroma was caramel, vanilla, wood and alcohol.  Taste was consistent with aroma.
Bomber. Murky orange brown pour with a small soapy head. Rich taste vs the aroma. Vanilla, caramel, and booze. Fairly hot. Good stuff.

Bottle shared at Gregs - thanks!! Nose is vanilla, some malt.
Taste is awesome - some soft booze up front then a sweet, soft toffee vanilla goodness. Really, really excellent beer.

Bottle shared by DalzAle. Pours hazy mahogany with a thin khaki head. Aroma has bitter whiskey and sweet caramel. Taste is sweet malt caramel woody whiskey and a smooth finish. Palate is full slick and dry. Very nice!

Bottle at THE Barley Wine Tasting, London. Thanks to Jack! Pours moderately cloudy ruby-gold with a fine, tan foam head. Caramelised dark fruit aroma, dark bread. Big sweet flavor with loads of fruit and caramel, brown sugar, fruit cake, booze, toffee. Full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Warming finish with lots of brown sugar, caramel, faint boozy tang, some figs. Nice, strong.

Bottle - 2011 vintage. Pours dark ruby with thick, frothy beige head; good retention and lacing. Aroma is cookie and bread malt, black cherries, figs, plums, floral hops, whiskey, oak, and light spice. Flavor is sweet malt forward with great dark fruit esters, booze, light floral esters and oak; sweet finish. Full body and low carbonation.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  Its a 2009 bottle.  It pours a muddy brown color with very low carbonation resulting in a thin cap of foam that doesnt last long.  The nose is a bit muddled and papery with light bourbon notes.  The flavor has notes of wood, medium bourbon, light vanilla, and fairly obvious oxidized notes.  I was really thinking this would hold up better than it did.  That being said, it was still a solid brew, just not outstanding.

Bottle shared by Marcus. Pours very ruddy brown with a transient head. Aromas of light bourbon and alcohol. Med + body. Flavor is cola, bourbon and some oak. Vanilla is hard for me with this one. Finishes towards dry with oak astringency. Good ale!

Bottle from the brewery. Pours orange brown with no head and a fruit and bourbon aroma. There is a delicious treacle and vanilla flavor with some cola and a tingly warm bourbon trail. This is a great sipper with a mellow oak presence.

Half snifter pour of hazed reddish brown with little to no head. Aroma is super chocolate, rich wood, booze and bourbon/whiskey with burnt sugar an caramel. Flavor is similar, quite boozy with whiskey up front followed with more burnt sugar and similar sweetness with chocolate. Oak is in there with nice smooth malt character and a not so well hidden alcohol, but very worth it. Smooth body, not too heavy, but quite drinkable.

Bottle 1563. $24.99. Pours a murky muddled reddisdh brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is leather, bourbon ,raisins, some vannilla, smells great. Taste is much sweeter than I expected, super sweet hints of caramel and raisins, much less hoppy than normal old ruffian, big hits of bourbon and vanilla, super complex, no hint at all of the abv, super slick mouthfeel, awesome brew glad to have tried it.

2011 bottle, thanks to arminjewell. 10/10/2012.  Pours rich, deep brown, light tan head, thick ring of lacing. This one really needs a bit of time to open up fully. Aroma is solidly whiskey, vanilla and wood, leathery, with subtle fruitiness gliding over fuller toffee character,butterscotch. Taste again prominently features that whiskey, but richer caramel, toffee maltiness is present, with a spicy hop character, boozy heat. Medium palate, but seems thin for the flavors. Alright, but something a little off-center for me.

Bottled at Big Beers and Barley Wines. Wow, this was great and dangerous considering how easy it was to drink this: not hint of the 12+ ABV. Super slick mouthfeel. Vanilla, booze, dark fruit and honey/syrup. Tasty and warming.

A lightly hazed copper amber ale with a thin creamy mocha head. In aroma, beautiful vinous malt with wooden notes, soy sauce, earthy celery salts, floral hops, licorice and alcohol. In mouth, a vinous malt with dark fruits, vanilla, wood, licorice, alcohol and fragrant hops. Tasted with GRM, Puskinwow, Boutip, Ian, Mike on Sept. 7 2012.

750ml bottle, #1561.  $29.99,  drank the whole thing.  Murky brown with small head.  Malty nose with some apple fruitiness, Burbons, and a slight touch of oxidation.  Great flavors that stand out.  Good mix of Burbons, vanillas, and enjoyable sweet toffee malts, with a touch of cherries.  Hop balance comes in the finish.  Very smooth, the alcohol takes a backseat.  Very good!

Bottle #3347 from 2011, pretty sure it was from adnielsen. Red mahogany with a faint tan head. Lots of whisky, yeast, celery, pepper, butter, alcohol, spice, fruit, malt - quite intense. Full body, moderate carbonation, tannins, somewhat sweet, alcohol is definitely present, figs and peach. Really liked this one.

Bottle: Poured a bright copper color ale with a medium size head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of whiskey is nice end very enticing with nice balanced sweet malt notes. Taste is a great balance between some whiskey notes with dry grain notes and a solid malt backbone with sweet caramel and light toffee notes. Body is quite full with medium carbonation and no apparent alcohol. I really enjoyed this one which I find had great balance between whisky and malt.

Bottle @ THE Barley Wine tasting. I think this is the one that pushed me past the point of no return....The aromas deep brown with a small white head. The nose is big booze, plenty of mocha chocolate, light red fruits. The taste is heavy sweet malt, bright accents of over-ripe fruits, some sweetened leather and booze. Big body, but the beer handles the alcohol gracefully. Overall, pretty excellent. On this night of epic barley wines, I felt only King Henry was better.

Bottle, thanks to Jack at THE Barley Wine Tasting, August 2012. It pours opaque dark brown, with a very thin off-white head. The nose is leather, wood, varnish, dark fruit and light roast. The taste is caramel, toffee, cherry, cola, alcohol warmth, toasted malt, charcoal and coffee, with a dry, warming finish. Full body, fine carbonation and slightly sticky mouth-feel. Very well balanced and pretty delicious. Definitely on the top tier of the barley wines we tried that fateful night....

Appearance: Pours a dark hazy copper with a lasting cap of tan froth.

Aroma: Burnt toffee/caramel, booze soaked oak. Dried apricot.

Taste: Burnt caramel, bitter hops, bourbon. Light tart apple/pear fruitiness. Very oaky.

Mouthfeel: Warm, astringent  with modest carbonation.

Overall: This was a bit too aggressive for my barrel aged barley wine tastes. Id like to revisit this after 2 years of cellaring.

(Flasche) Es hat ein dunkles, warmes Braun, es ist unfiltriert mit einer bräunlichen Schaumkrone. Das Aroma ist erdig, süß, holzig, etwas würzig und fast lakritzartig. Geschmacklich ist es sehr vollmundig, dunkle Beere, leicht erdig, süß und etwas nach Bretanomyces, aber fast ohne Bittere.
Pours red minimal head, hazy. Smell is sweet citrus. Taste is sweet caramel, huge yeastieness, toffee, oak and vanilla. Good, but probably not worth the price.

750 ML bottle 333/1188
Last of my 09 BA Great Divide beers


A-- Poured a dark, murky, orange brown color. Muddy would be the best way to describe this beer. One finger tan head that settled to a solid tan film through drinking. Good spotty lacing on the sides of the glass. 

S-- Barrel is noticeable in the nose. Oak, leather and whisky. Solid stuff. Underneath the barrel notes got stewed plumbs, some Graham Cracker and a solid hop presence still. ABV is well masked for a near 13% beer. 

T-- Was quite unhappy with the first half of my glass as it was quite thin and watery. Once it got air it picked up in a big way. Very earthy, grainy, Carmel strawberry jam and hearty bread. Just flashes of oak and touches of whisky to round out the jam notes. 

M-- Decent amount of tannins left on gums. Left them numb for a few minutes. Still has the ABV punch. Low carbonation and not all that heavy until the end. Slightly slick and oily due to the hops. 

O-- Conflicted as liked the beer but in reality prefer regular Ruffian more. Might be showing its age a bit as was thin in spots and needed a lot of air to open this up. Decent enough stuff but not on par with other BA barleywines out there. Not as much substance to the body as others out there.

11 bottle.  Murky reddish pour with a nice froth of light tan foam.  Aroma is dry and thin whiskey with earthy faded hops that give off a slightly decayed aroma.  Taste is heavy on the whisky from start to finish with the base beer coming through in the middle and showing caramel, raisin, toffee, and faded hops.  Bit of an off flavor in there as well that is hard to pin down.  I cannot say that this is infected per se but something does not quite seem right.  Nice enough beer just the same but perhaps it is sitting in an odd place now as the hops fade out.

Bottle. Pours a nice ruby red color with an off white head. Aroma is of oak, vanilla, bourbon, dark fruits, toasted malt, red grapes, caramel, toffee, sweet malts and light tobacco note. The flavor follows the nose with lots of vanilla and bourbon, the light vinous note, red grapes, toasted malt, caramel, nutty notes, toffee, sweet malt, light tobacco and dark fruits. The body is full with a silky mouth feel. Overall a really nice Barley Wine!

Goddamn.  I expected a great but a bit difficult to drink beer.  This is so smooth.  Well balanced alcohol that doesnt hit you on the nose.  Little head from the tap.  Nice aromatics with nothing overwhelming.  Such a good beer.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured hazy reddish brown color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy dark fruit, toasted malt, bourbon alcohol and wood aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Moderate to heavy dark fruit bourbon sweet flavor with a medium to heavy dark sweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is a complex solid beer.

Pours a very dark reddish brown with a creamy beige head leaving nice thick lacing behind. The aroma is pancakes and syrup, tobacco, chocolate, caramel, a touch of red wine, oak, and hops. The taste is all of the above and manages to transcend all of these individual qualities into something far superior as a whole. Complex yet accessible. Outstanding and perfect in my book.

21/07 RBESG Grand Tasting, 0.75 l bottle. It poured hazy copper body with medium sized head. Very nice dried fruit and caramel aroma, touch with a medicinal scent, but just a little bit. Sweet flavor, ripe fruits, caramel, vanilla sugar, tobacco and hint of chocolate. A bit crude also, alcohol is quite present, making it also slightly bitter. Medium bodied with long, warming, sweetish finish. A nice barley wine, but it would be interesting to see how it would taste matured.
Sample at Natifest. Dark, sort of clear color. Thin khaki head. Bourbon, good smokey wood aroma. Toasty. Light carbonation, dry texture. Bitter, warmth in the taste, some savory. Interesting brew.

Bottle picked up at the brewery from a recent Denver visit and drank at home all for me!

Dark amber to reddish brown in colour with a half finger of off-white head.
Dark fruits on the nose - prunes/figs and pinch of vanilla and the Stranahans whisky is a background aroma.
Dried fruits in the taste, also sensing cherries and a little bitter chocolate. Sugary and another hint of the whisky.  Whisky again in the background and not taking over which is great by me.

(bottle) pours a very hazy ruby colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of treebark, caramel and straciatella yoghurt, cherries, herbal hops, banana and just a hint of vanilla. flavour is mostly the same, the caramel and banana being dominant, quite sweet. heavy-bodied with average carbonation.

Bottle, RBESG 2012 grand tasting. Medium dark brown colour. Aroma earthy, sweet, raisins, peat. Taste almost heavy sweet, cognac, caramel, peat, smoke, wood, alcohol. Alcohol well hidden in the complex taste. Finish is medium bitter and sweet, alcohol warm. Very good.

Poured a misty dark red body with an off white head. Sticky nose, dried cranberries mostly. The taste is sticky too, but nice, honeyish, slightly peaty. Figs, rosewater?, vanilla, warming alcohol - a lovely sweet barleywine!
RBESG Grand tasting. Hazy amber color with beige head. Aroma of dark fruits,molasses, caramel, vanilla, wood. Taste, dark fruits, vanilla, caramel, oak.  Nice.

Big thanks to frosty!  This one pours deep deep red. Head is small and fades to a film. Nose is strong vanilla, oak, bourbon, spice, cinnamon, nuts, and some booze. Bottle #1254. Pours a muddy amber with a medium, frothy, tan head. The aroma is intense candy (butterscotch, caramel, toffee), oak, some earthy hops, dark fruits, and molasses. 2012 version.  Dark red pour with a tan head, caramel malts, boozy, dark fruitiness  and a little vanilla on the nose, taste is wonderful with a little caramel, vanilla with some chocolately to go along with the whiskey booziness.  Absolutely awesome beer.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2013 2008 Vintage (#78/461) 750ml bottle with a bottled on date of April 08 and a 12.7% ABV compared side-by-side with a 2012 (#0860) 750ml bottle that has an 11.8% ABV. 2008  Pours a murky, deep amber, slightly orange tinted body with a finger-width, creamy, tannish beige head that dissipates slowly and leaves lots of pretty lacing. Gorgeous beer. Aroma seems a bit messy at this point. Its pretty sweet and the malts seem oxidized. The hops havent completely gone away, but only a light floral and earthy citrus note remains. A bit of an orange note from the hops mixes with lots of caramel and some toffee. There is still plenty of oak that gives off a bit of a char note, but also seems to accentuate the oxidization of the malts. A light raisin and date note along with some brown sugar. Flavor is similar with the oak really dominating while the malts dont give off the oxidization that the aroma displayed. Maybe the accidental 20-month aging helped with the oaks presence. The malts arent as complex as the fresher bottle, but they have aged nicely with lots of rich caramels, toffees, and a light molasses. A light orange comes out again from the floral and earthy hops mixing with the malts as this makes way for a big, pretty dry woodiness. The beer is sweet enough and big enough to handle the oak, but if this were any thinner the oak would be way over-the-top. A light vanilla and a bit of a whisky note mixes nicely with the oak. Some brown sugar and a touch of chocolate towards the end as some dates and raisins make their way into the mix. Finishes dry from the big woodiness and all-of-a-sudden, lots of vanilla shows up along with a sweet malt backing and light dark fruit note that isnt nearly as rich and deep as the 2012 bottle. Medium bitterness and a touch of booze before leaving a lengthy aftertaste with lots of wood and vanilla. Medium, smooth body that was probably thinned a bit from the extended aging with a soft, medium-light carbonation. Overall, I was expecting to like this bottle more than the 2012 because Ive been carefully cellaring it for four years and it was the original release, but this is no where near as good as the fresher version. This may be passed its climax or maybe it was aged too long on wood, but I did enjoy it nonetheless. The aroma seemed oxidized, but it didnt show up in the flavor. The oak is really dominant and Im guessing it was way over-the-top when this was first released, but throughout the years it seems to have blended well with the malts that have also settled into their own. I like the bigger vanilla note that comes out towards the end and despite this being thinner than the 2012 bottle, it still has a really nice palate. Im very glad to have had the opportunity to pick this up in Denver four years ago and hold onto it like I have, but if anyone still has a bottle of the original release, I would drink it now before the flavor gets oxidized (6,5,7,4,13=3.5).2012 Vintage  Pours a cloudy, deep amber, slightly orange tinted, but less so than the 2008 bottle with a finger-width, creamy, tannish beige head thats a bit lighter than the 2008 while dissipating slowly and leaving lots of pretty lacing too. Absolutely gorgeous. Aroma is awesome. Sweeter with lots of heavy caramels and some molasses along with a slight boozy note that dies after an initial whiff and plenty of aggressive hops that are floral and earthy. Pleasant oak and a light whiskey note with some rich dark fruits consisting mostly of dates and raisins. Plenty of toffees come out as this warms along with a nice vanilla, a touch of chocolate, and some brown sugar. Flavor is absolutely wonderful. Rich dates and raisins with deep caramels, toffee, molasses, brown sugar, and a light chocolate up front. Lots of oak in the middle with a soft vanilla that blends so well with the sweetness of the malts. A sturdy amount of earthy and floral hops that also balances the malts while never distracting from the pleasant oak and nice whiskey note that comes out more towards the end. Finishes nicely dry from the oak and hops, but rich, deep, and sweet from the malts and dark fruits with an awesome vanilla note coming out more as this warms. Medium bitterness before leaving a lengthy aftertaste. Full, creamy, smooth body and a soft, medium-light carbonation. Overall, an absolutely breathtaking barleywine. The malts are sweet and complex, but never cloying. Lots of hops to balance, but they never distract from the malts or the barrel aging that offers plenty of oak, vanilla, and a very pleasant whiskey note. Remarkable palate and no hint of booze that reminds me that yes, I do want to drink this forever and ever and ever. Wowthis just might be the best beer Ive ever had. Drink this NOW. Utterly stunning (9,5,10,5,18=4.7).

750 @dmacs willblake is back in NJ tasting-thanks dmac pours copper with offwhite bubbles.  Aroma is medium/dark fruit-dates, 2nd medium malt-peat.  Taste is medium/dark fruit-dates, 2nd medium malt-peat/wood.

Here it is more like good old straight old wood barrels and it dries out the beer very nicely and adds a pleasant light astringency. 2009 vintage. Thanks to FeDUBBELFIST for sharing. 

Pours a dark amber/chestnut brown color with mahogany edges and a half finger beige head that quickly settles into a thin ring. Sporadic spots of lace left behind.

2008, Bottle 100/461; Sampled October 2011
An aggressive pour into my Lost Abbey Teku glass produces a fat, finger thick, amber tinged full tan colored head.  The beer is a dark, concentrated amber / brown that shows a murky, dark amber color when held up to the light.  The aroma smells strongly of bourbon, alcohol, toasted coconut, big vanillin notes, tart whiskey notes, whiskey soaked caramel, perhaps a touch of salty smokiness and a bit of sherry; these last two notes are definitely the effect of some oxidation.  The biggest notes by far in the aroma are sweetened, almost caramelized, toasted coconut and vanillin, which is followed closely by a general whiskey character; the base beer plays a distant role in the nose, which is great if you really like whiskey, but if you were looking for a Barleywine then you might be a bit disappointed (which I am a bit).  As the beer warms up, the caramelized malt portion of the aroma starts to pick up a bit; when combined with the barrel notes it almost reminds me a bit of cotton candy at times, in some weird way.  Some toasted, whole grain character also becomes a bit more noticeable in the aroma.

Bitter, slightly herbal hop flavors are anchored by a toasted and richly caramelized malt character that is enhanced by flavors of toasted coconut and vanillin.  The finish dries out with a big hop bitterness that provides quite a bite as well as some green hop astringency; this is accentuated by some woody spiciness and some warming, sometimes hot, whiskey flavors and alcohol.  The body of this beer is fairly luscious, though it has certainly significantly thinned from the base beer; the body along with the spiciness from the oak makes this a definite sipping brew though.  The hop flavor has significantly faded in this brew, but it is still a bit harsh & it makes me wonder how this was drinking when it was a much younger beer.  Towards the middle and more towards the finish there is a slightly nutty flavor that shows the touch of oxidation and there is also a touch of sherry or even wet cardboard perhaps.

This is another barrel aged beer that spent way too much time in the barrel, alternatively this should have been blended with some fresh Old Ruffian as I am really wishing the base beer came through in some way.  As it is this is purely a vehicle for the Stranahan barrels, if that is your thing then you will enjoy this beer, but if you are looking for beer then you might be a bit disappointed.  I am enjoying this beer a little bit, so it is not a complete loss, but not enough to remotely want to finish this bottle by myself (I might finish my glass).

text: 750ml bottle.  The pour yields a cloudy, dark, caramel brown body with a small, swirly film of light beige foam at the head.  A thick wash of suds mostly sheet back down the glass, though trace spots remain behind to dry.  The nose is primarily rich and malty, showing notes of dark caramel, brown butter, burnt toffee, and soft cocoa.  Remnants of earthen hops lend trace amounts of balancing bitterness, while the charred oak imparts silky vanilla and woody bourbon notes.  It simply smells fantastic, and the flavor doesnt disappoint.  Lush caramel and buttery toffee prove the perfect backdrop for the oaky, vanilla laden bourbon, and theres just enough cocoa roast and barrel char to keep the sweetness from getting out of hand.  The big but slightly thinned palate benefits from the oak aging, picking up a welcomed touch of drying oxidation and softened carbonation.  Excellent beer.  Delicious, wintertime, front porch type of slow sipper.

2009 vintage.  Bottle 297/1188. Havent had the original in a while and didnt try the first barrel-aged Ruffian.  Pours with a murky, crimson-brick color with an average, beige, tight, pillowy head which is somewhat lasting and leaves a thin layer of froth but minimal lace.  Nose is still young but pleasant with toasted oak and toasted caramel, faint vanilla and cotton candy, spicy bourbon, underlying apricot, maybe floral, lightly buttery, and faint amaretto.  Kind of surprised that it is still young and not much hops noted.  The flavor is much different with some more hops noted; piney and oaky (almost rustic-like), grapefruit and apricot, toasted notes, light bourbon, spicy (almost cayenne-like), buttery toffee, and faint amaretto.  Palate is perfect with a full body, prickly but nearly soft carbonation, round, chewy, velvety, and nice warmth.  Finishes drying a bit, more than moderately bitter but seemingly more due to the spicy character, and notes of cayenne, buttery toffee, Stranahans, and some oaken vanilla with pine and spice lingering.  This is one the barrel-aged beers from GD that I think actually improved the beer.  Maybe it is the fact that I actually love the original Yeti and Hibernation and just like the Ruffian (and BW in general), but somehow the bourbon and oak notes help add depth to an intensely rich and hoppy beer.  My only wish is that GD could make these barrel-aged beers less than $25.  Awesome palate and nice flavor and one of the best whiskey-aged beers in a while.
